title: I Only Want Hearing Aidsâ€”Today!
chief_complaint: I am here to purchase better performing hearing aids. My current ones aren't working well, and I don't want to discuss my medical history.

problem_summary.onset: Dizziness began in 2000; severe vertigo event in July 2011. Hearing loss has been progressive.
problem_summary.course: Progressive hearing loss bilaterally, with the left ear declining more rapidly. Vestibular symptoms have persisted.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Dizziness with high-intensity sound (Tullio phenomenon), imbalance, heavy pressure-headed sensation, tinnitus (left ear), diplopia.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Unable to enjoy walking; symptoms exacerbated by complex visual environments, loud noises, and rapid head movements. Poor hearing aid performance.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Primary initial goal was to buy new hearing aids immediately without medical evaluation.

history.present_illness: Patient presented demanding to buy hearing aids. Refused to discuss medical history initially. Disclosed dizziness with loud sounds.
history.otologic_history: Provided two previous audiograms (2012 and 2015) from an otolaryngologist showing degradation of left ear hearing.
history.prior_management: Saw otolaryngologist in 2012 and 2015. Currently wearing RIC hearing aids from Costco.

tests.name: Review of Historical Audiometry (2012)
tests.key_findings: Right ear: Moderate SNHL sloping to severe. Left ear: Moderately severe mixed loss with air-bone gaps. Poor word recognition on left.

tests.name: Review of Historical Audiometry (2015)
tests.key_findings: Significant degradation in left ear thresholds. No air-bone gaps noted (Type A tymps reported in text). WRS in left ear dropped significantly.

history.present_illness: Patient returned after visiting a vestibular clinic. More amenable to questions. Reports dizziness, imbalance, and pressure sensation.
history.medical_psych_history: Anxiety, depression, sleep apnea (CPAP), hypothyroidism. History of pelvic radiation.
history.vestibular_history: Vestibular clinic results (outside): 78% caloric weakness LE, abnormal phase lead, short VOR time constants.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Asymmetric SNHL. Right: Moderate flat to 2k sloping to severe. Left: Severe to profound flat loss. No conductive component found (Type A tymps).

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Excellent recognition in right ear; very poor recognition in left ear (rollover/retrocochlear sign).

tests.name: Immittance & Reflexes
tests.key_findings: Normal tympanograms (Type A). Acoustic reflexes absent ipsilateral and contralateral.

tests.name: Real Ear Measures (REM)
tests.key_findings: Current Costco hearing aids found to be well below NAL-NL-2 targets.

tests.name: MRI Internal Auditory Canal
tests.key_findings: 1.5 cm lesion along left cerebellopontine angle extending into porus acusticus and IAC. Cochlea/vestibule normal.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with a significant asymmetric sensorineural hearing loss, characterized by a moderate-to-severe loss in the right ear and a severe-to-profound loss in the left ear. Word recognition is excellent in the right ear but disproportionately poor in the left ear (32%), consistent with retrocochlear pathology. Diagnostic testing reveals absent acoustic reflexes and significant signal-to-noise ratio loss (23.5 dB). MRI confirmed a 1.5 cm vestibular schwannoma on the left side.
counseling_points: Your hearing test shows a significant difference between your ears, which is a 'red flag' requiring medical investigation.
The MRI results confirm a growth (vestibular schwannoma) on the hearing nerve of your left ear, which explains the dizziness and rapid hearing drop.
We need to refer you to a neurotologist to discuss management options like surgery or radiation.

Regarding hearing aids: Your ability to understand speech in the left ear is very poor, even with amplification. We will need to set realistic expectations for how much a hearing aid can help on that side.
notes_for_actor: In the first encounter, be defensive, impatient, and focused solely on buying a product ('The customer is always right'). Refuse to answer medical questions.
Express frustration that the audiologist won't just sell you the aids.
In later encounters, after the medical scare and failed appointment, become more cooperative and open about your symptoms.
Portray the dizziness as a heavy, pressure-headed sensation that makes walking difficult.
